overview.title: The Sacred Mountain
overview.subtitle: Spiritual Center of Four Great Religions
overview.description: Mount Kailash stands as one of the most sacred places on Earth, revered by over a billion people across four distinct religious traditions. Unlike mountains celebrated for conquest, Kailash draws pilgrims seeking spiritual transformation through devotion, not dominion.

religions.name: Hinduism
religions.title: Abode of Lord Shiva
beliefs: Kailash is identified as Mount Meru, the axis of the universe
Lord Shiva sits in eternal meditation at the summit with Goddess Parvati
The four faces of the mountain are made of crystal, ruby, gold, and lapis lazuli
The mountain represents the lingam, with Lake Manasarovar as the yoni—symbols of cosmic creation
practices: Pilgrims often perform the journey on foot, some with full-body prostrations
Bathing in Lake Manasarovar purifies the soul
Many pilgrims carry sacred water home for ceremonies
scriptures: Vishnu Purana describes Meru as the center of the universe
Shiva Purana details Shiva's eternal presence on Kailash
Skanda Purana contains extensive descriptions of the sacred geography
Ramayana mentions Kailash as Shiva's celestial abode

religions.name: Tibetan Buddhism
religions.title: Home of Buddha Demchok
beliefs: Kailash is the palace of Buddha Demchok (Chakrasamvara), embodying supreme bliss
The mountain represents the spiritual center of the Buddhist tantric tradition
Milarepa's victory here established Buddhism's spiritual authority
The landscape reflects the Buddhist mandala—a sacred cosmic diagram
practices: One kora erases sins of a lifetime
13 koras permit one to attempt the inner kora
108 koras can lead to enlightenment in this very life
Pilgrims leave prayer flags, perform mantras, and make prostrations
scriptures: Chakrasamvara Tantra describes the sacred landscape
Songs of Milarepa recount his spiritual contest at Kailash
Various Tibetan texts detail pilgrimage routes and spiritual practices

religions.name: Jainism
religions.title: Ashtapada - Site of Liberation
beliefs: Kailash is Ashtapada, where Rishabhadeva achieved moksha (liberation)
Rishabhadeva was the first of 24 Tirthankaras (spiritual teachers)
His grandson Bharata built a temple at the summit
The mountain marks the ultimate spiritual achievement
practices: Pilgrimage to Kailash is a lifetime spiritual goal
Jains circumambulate while reciting prayers and mantras
The journey represents the soul's path to liberation
Many Jains visit during auspicious calendar dates
scriptures: Various Digambara and Shvetambara texts reference the sacred site

religions.name: Bon
religions.title: Seat of All Spiritual Power
beliefs: Kailash is the sacred nine-story Swastika Mountain
Founder Tonpa Shenrab descended from heaven to Kailash
The mountain is the axis connecting heaven, earth, and underworld
Spiritual power emanates from Kailash to all directions
practices: Bon practitioners circumambulate counter-clockwise (opposite to other religions)
This direction honors the counter-clockwise swastika symbol of Bon
Pilgrims perform elaborate rituals at specific sacred sites
The journey reconnects practitioners with the source of spiritual power
scriptures: Bon texts describe Kailash as the original sacred mountain
Stories of Tonpa Shenrab detail the heavenly connection
Ancient Bon cosmology places Kailash at the universe's center

points.title: Axis Mundi
points.description: All four traditions view Kailash as the cosmic axis connecting heaven, earth, and the underworld—the spiritual center of existence.

points.title: Transformative Power
points.description: Each tradition believes circumambulating Kailash purifies the soul and can lead to spiritual liberation or enlightenment.

points.title: Sacred Geography
points.description: The mountain and surrounding lakes form a sacred landscape that mirrors cosmic patterns and divine geometries.

points.title: Prohibition of Climbing
points.description: All traditions agree that Kailash should never be climbed—the mountain is meant for devotion, not conquest.

quote.text: Kailash is a place of pilgrimage, not a target for conquest. Those who come here seeking peaks to climb have missed its essence entirely.
quote.author: Traditional saying
